body:
Hi @clarkewd,

thanks for the detailed writeup. :-) It looks like all your assumptions are correct so far - your issue might be way simpler: The "Enable transparent HTTP proxying" checkbox should be disabled in Charles. In upstream mode, mitmproxy assumes a regular proxy upstream, not a transparent one.

Let me know if that works for you. Otherwise, we'll have to dig deeper.

Cheers,
Max

Max - thanks so much for the quick response! Per your suggestion I tried unchecking the box for `Enable transparent HTTP proxying` but I'm still not having any luck. What options should I be using at the command line? I'm not afraid to do some testing if you can point me in the right direction. Although python isn't my language of choice, I did spent several hours going through the `proxy.py` file and attempting (hackishly) to debug by writing variables to a named pipe ( a la `pprint(vars(self.server_conn), stream=the_file)` ). (I think that) I understand how the SSL proxying works. I have been using Charles by itself for a long time. I've been reading up on mitmproxy and have been through most of the `libmproxy` source and am really comfortable with this whole concept: With two SSL proxies both doing this it seems that the one connecting to the website would be able to communicate with the site using it's own cert signing, and then the proxy that was communicating with the browser would also do the same thing - so this should work, right? I also noticed that if I set the proxy to `-U "https://localhost:8888"` which means "hey, use Charles as a the upstream proxy and communicate with it via SSL" - and then if I visit a plain (HTTP) website I get: ``` ProxyError(ProxyError(...), "SSL handshake error: [('SSL routines', 'SSL3_GET_RECORD', 'wrong version number')]") ``` So that sort of looks like `mitmproxy` does not like the cert that Charles is issuing to it. Does `mitmproxy` have something that is similar to `curl`'s `-k, --insecure` which does not verify the proxy's cert? I was attempting to figure out how to edit the `proxy.py` file to test that theory. Thanks for your help.

Hi @clarkewd,

thanks for the detailed explanation - I think I identified the issue, give me half an hour.

Cheers,
Max

Time for a little more detailed response :-) First: I added a fix for your issue and verified that mitmproxy is working with Charles now. If you update mitmproxy to git master, simply specifying `mitmproxy -U http://localhost:8888/` should work. Let me answer your other questions raised here as well: > I don't think I can try "socks5://localhost:8888" (yet) correct (and linked to the right issue) > I see that in the 0.11 there is something regarding a new protocol - 2https - is that something that could be used to achieve this? using the https2http:// syntax, mitmproxy can terminate SSL connections in a reverse proxy scenario (or vice versa). In other words, one could use mitmproxy to "sslify" any HTTP website. > With two SSL proxies both doing this it seems that the one connecting to the website would be able to communicate with the site using it's own cert signing, and then the proxy that was communicating with the browser would also do the same thing - so this should work, right? yep. `browser <---> proxy 1 <---> proxy 2 <---> server`, each `<--->` represents an isolated end-to-end SSL connection. > I also noticed that if I set the proxy to -U "https://localhost:8888" Strictly speaking, there's no thing such as a HTTPS proxy. We have an HTTP proxy upstream that understands CONNECT requests (and tunnels data afterwards). In the case of mitmproxy, we intercept as well, but that's a different story :stuck_out_tongue: This is why a https upstream proxy doesn't work/makes no sense. > Does mitmproxy have something that is similar to curl's -k, --insecure which does not verify the proxy's cert? I was attempting to figure out how to edit the proxy.py file to test that theory. mitmproxy does not attempt to validate upstream certificates at all, so it's `--insecure` by default. If you have any further questions, let me know! Cheers, Max
very awesome - it's working now! thanks for the quick fix and the very detailed follow up!

Hi, Is it working this way?
Client<---https--->MITMproxy<----HTTP---> Charles

Thanks
Yes it is just as @mhils said it would.

@salmancom, 

`browser <---> mitmproxy <---> charles <---> server`, each `<--->` represents an isolated end-to-end SSL/HTTPS connection.

Cheers,
Max
Thanks.... Then I should try to change the source code to do this :)

@salmancom,

may I ask what you want to accomplish?

Cheers,
Max

We need to build an offline MITM proxy:

client <--https--> MITM <--- http --> Database

where database is set of previously recorded decrypted SSL request/responses.

issue.title: configure mitmproxy(2.0.2) as Upstream proxy to Charles()

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
Hi,

I tried to configure mitmproxy in upstream proxy mode to Charles(4.2) as was described [here](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/313)

In my case there is the following scheme:

Client(Roku)<---https/http--->MITMproxy<----HTTP/HTTPS---> Charles

I  trusted the root CA cert in my keychain and even imported mitmproxy-ca-cert.p12 into Charles
If I run mitmproxy -T --host(in the transparent mode) without redirecting the request to Charles I'm able to view both http/https requests
If I send requests directly to Charles("Enable transparent HTTP proxying" option is enabled) I can view HTTP traffic

The reason why I'm trying to put mitmproxy in the middle between my Roku device and Charles is to handle HTTPS traffic as well

When I start mitmproxy in the upstream mode(mitmproxy -U "http://localhost:8888") and forward all the requests to Charles("Enable transparent HTTP proxying" option is disabled) the Roku application simply crushes 
In the even log I found - HTTP protocol error in client request: Invalid HTTP request form (expected: authority or absolute, got: relative)
In the Charles Contents tab - com.xk72.proxy.http.HttpFieldsException: Invalid first line in request

Could you please advise if I can catch/handle HTTP/HTTPS traffic in the way described above?

./mitmproxy --version
Mitmproxy version: 2.0.2 (release version) Precompiled Binary
Python version: 3.5.2
Platform: Linux-4.10.0-38-generic-x86_64-with-debian-stretch-sid
SSL version: OpenSSL 1.1.0e  16 Feb 2017
Linux distro: debian stretch/sid
